title: Has lexicography reaped the full benefit of the (learner) corpus revolution?

author: Sylviane Granger, Centre for English Corpus Linguistics, University of Louvain

segmentation: I would like to thank the organizing committee and in particular seem on crack and also the Hornby Trust for inviting me to give the Hornby lecture at this year's conference.
It's a great honor to give a lecture bearing the name of Albert Sidney Hornby and also quite a challenge, so I hope you will find me worthy of the honor.
Actually, the Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary of current English was the first monolingual Dictionary of English I ever owned.
It was on my list of required books when I started my studies as an English undergraduate at the University of Louisville.
In 1968, exactly 50 years ago.
Wow.

Today I'm going to talk about the corpus revolution.
In 1992 rental and Stock published a long three part article entitled The Corpus Revolution.
In which they highlighted the major changes brought about by the emergence of corpora.
And this is what they wrote.
The past decade has witnessed a revolution in the nature.
Of linguistic data available to writers of dictionaries, and this has led to the questioning and in some cases the abandonment of working practices established over 200 years ago.
In 2008 Michael Randall published a second article entitled the Corpus Revolution Revisited.
And this time he described a second revolution.
